description:
WejdÅº w ReakcjÄ™: Zaginiony eksperyment (Re-action:Lost Experiment) is a hybrid of escape room game and experimental kit. The box contains:

     deck of cards with riddles and quizes, which allows players to participate in exciting laboratory investigation
     experimental kit of reagents and tools to conduct 10 biochemical experiments.


Joined two different worlds (science and boardgames) provides an unique thematic, immersive game.

WejdÅº w ReakcjÄ™: Zaginiony eksperyment was published thanks to cooperation of Games Development (boardgame publisher) and BioCen (Foundation of bioeducation).

—description from the designer

For What Remains is a skirmish-level series of three wargames set in a post-apocalyptic near future: 

    Streets of Ruin
    Blood on the Rails
    Out of the Basement


Out of the Basement features the Erthen and Order of the New Dawn factions, set in the Out of the Basement campaign. The Erthen are a biologically developed race formed from a mixture of human, mineral, and organic matter, and the Order of the New Dawn are creatures from the strange subterranean realm known as the Basement.

The game is designed for 2-player competitive play or solitaire play, and each set can be played by itself standalone, or combined with other sets to form a larger narrative. Players control characters from one of the game’s six Factions.

There are two ways to play For What Remains: skirmishes and campaigns. Skirmishes are standalone games played for a single victory, with no lasting repercussions. Campaigns are a series of skirmishes linked together to form a larger narrative. For What Remains is a scenario driven game. Each scenario typically has multiple objectives, and combat between factions is usually secondary. Players win skirmishes by gaining victory points through accomplishing these objectives.

The game board is built from modular tiles which are themed to represent different environments. The default game board is a destroyed urban setting. Players build the game board with nine modular tiles, each of which are divided into a 7x7 grid. Characters use the grids for movement.

Each character is represented by a counter and has a corresponding character card and tokens. During campaign play, characters improve their attributes and develop new abilities as they progress from Recruit to Veteran and then Elite level. A chit pull system is used for unit activation, and a step-loss system is used for tracking injuries during skirmishes.

—description from the designer

In Hey Yo: The Card Game with a Beat, you all play cards to a shared music chart so that you can ideally create solid rhythms and score points. The game includes a small dedicated device that you can use to accompany the gameplay, with players needing to play a card when the music indicates this. If you can't play in time to the rhythm, you're penalized, so you must talk quickly to share information and decide which cards to play. (Alternatively, you can play music of your choice to set the rhythm of play for the game.)

Hey Yo includes two identical decks of cards, so instead of playing a co-operative game with 2-5 players, you can have 4-10 players split into teams to compete against one another.

CzóÅ‚ko Junior is a family edition of the popular party game CzÃ³Å‚ko, in which players guess phrases using questions. There are as many as 330 phrases in 8 categories on the illustrated cards, thanks to which the game will ensure a long fun for the whole family.

Choices transports players into the world of decision making. It is an adventure of thought that begins with a dilemma and ends with a choice. Tucked in between is competition, verbal action, and a lot of guesswork.

—description from the back of the box

Plan'it is a competitive and strategic card game for 2 to 4 players, in which you should be the first traveller who explores the six continents. For achieve you goal, you must live three kind of experiences: adventure, nature and cultural trips. However, you are not the only passionated traveller in the game, other characters are trying to visit the whole world before you.

The carddeck is really artistic and original, because the cards have a key color in their back part. Thus, other players could suposse your strategy, and they will try to sabbotagge it, but only you are the one who knows which country is the next in your plan. You have to "plan it" properly, because you must manage your budget for your trips, but also the weather conditions and you must combinate the three experiences (adventure, nature and culture).

Are you ready to live the adventure of exploring the world from your table?

Superhero — or supervillain? You decide in this buildable dice game. Your customizable dice pool is used to execute a variety of superpowers. Gain special abilities and new play experiences by taking on the role of six different heroes or villains.

In KAPOW!, players go head-to-head in a classic explosive clash of good vs. evil. You choose to be a villain or hero, which determines your starting trait dice and unique abilities. You can gain additional blank "action dice" that have removable faces that that you customize to your liking to best enhance your character. Behind a player screen, you roll dice, then allocate them to attack, defense, and power-up abilities. The combination of choosing how to grow your dice pool, how to customize your action die faces, and how to use each roll leads to a satisfying, strategic showdown.

KAPOW! Volume 1 contains six supers: Tough Nut, Elusivity, and Time Out are the heroes, while Victor Kane, Coquette, and Spoiler Alert are the villains. This set can be combined with KAPOW! Volume 2 to mix and match the characters or have up to four players in one game.

The board game that requires creativity, strategy and a little back stabbing. Make your finest sculpture in a short amount of time and try to avoid your friends crushing your creations, and your dreams.

The basic premise is each round there is a new judge. The judge selects an idea card for the players to create during the round. A time limit is selected and the players frantically sculpt. The judge rank the sculptures on the table and the players will move accordingly. 1st place moves forward 3 spaces, 2nd place moves two spaces, 3rd place moves 3 spaces, and the rest don’t move at all.

Along the way you will encounter rule squares, penalty squares and star squares, if you land on one of them, pick up a card with the corresponding symbol. Penalty squares make you sculpt with one hand or move back a space, stuff like that. Star squares typically give players the best card in the game, a Clay Crusher card. This means at the end of any future round the player can use their Clay Crusher card to smash another player's creation before the judge sees it. First one around the board wins!

-description from publisher

You wake up in a cryogenic chamber at the same time as the other players. As soon as you come to your senses, a voice announces: "Welcome to our game. You are aboard the Spartacus ship, which sails not far from the planet Pandora."

Your goal is to be a player to stay alive. You take turns opening a door to the ship. Behind each door you will find either a bloodthirsty monster or equipment that can help you survive. The last survivor will be released.

Each player chooses one of the characters, receives a flamethrower and six cards.

Each player in turn draws a card (it is the opening of the door) look at it and places it in front of him face down.

On his turn a player can play as many cards from his hand (or none), then he must open his door (the card face down in front of him).

If the player draws an Alien or Arachnid card when he opens his door, the player must show it to the other players.

If he has a flamethrower, he discards it and draws a new door and his turn is over (if he doesn't have a flamethrower, he dies).

If the player does not draw a monster, this card enters their hand.

Finally, the player replaces his door with a new one.

—description from the publisher

Croc'Attack is a board game born in Crocodile Land (a.k.a Australia!) featuring Crocodiles eating people and Treasure Hunters crossing narrow bridges to find treasures on an island. 
This game is adapted for 8+ yo, for 3 to 5 players.

Each player gets a pawn. One player should play the Crocodile, the rest of the players are treasure hunters.

Crocodiles:

     Prevent Hunters from accessing the island,
     Protect your treasures,
     And eat as many hunters as possible!


Treasure hunter:

     Access the island and steal as many treasures as possible,
     Avoid being eaten by the crocodile,
     Get more treasures than the other hunters.


The Treasure Hunters can move anywhere on the Land tiles / Bridges tiles or on the Island. The crocodile cannot reach them when they are on the Land tiles or Island, but the crocodile can access the Bridge tiles.

The games stops when all the Treasure Hunters are dead, or when there is no more Treasures to steal on the island. Points are then calculated to determine the winner.

—description from the designer

Pro Cycling The Board Game is 2020’s latest cycling board game, a fun and tactical game from the world of pro series. In the game you have to control a professional cycling team and get the most points by the end of the game. The following game items are available for this.

1.    Team organization: From the five-person frame, assemble a four-person team according to the conditions of the race track – for the flat sections SPRINTER, for the mountain sections CLIMBER, and a LEADER who leads the team.
2.    PELOTON: The field that is uniquely part of the competition.
3.    Track knowledge: Mapping the race track and getting to know the most important action points.
-    The colorful lines on both sides of the racing track indicate the difficulty level of the
    road and the level of steepness.
-    PART SPRINT: You can also earn valuable points during the race.
-    REFRESHING POINT: Additional action cards can be drawn.
-    BIG FALL, TECHNICAL ERROR: Various disadvantages can be obtained.
4.    Game dice and action die: The player makes the moves using the two dice.
5.    Action Cards: Action cards can be used to launch actions.
-    BREAKAWAY CARD: This card can be used to break away from the peloton.
-    ATTACK CARD: It gives the player an opportunity for a quick attack.
-    PELOTON CARD: Used to increase the pace of the field.
6.    In addition to action cards, other special actions can be used, such as a sprint, helping each other, helping the leader.

The board game is not only for bike fans, but also offers fun for the whole family. The number of players: 2-4 people. The duration of a game is 40-60 minutes depending on the number of players. The rulebook is available in the following languages: Hungarian, English, German, French, Italian, Spanish.

Buy your favorite North Dakota properties, increase your rent by collecting Cabins and trading them for Lodges.  Sound easy?  Well, add in some lawnmower racing, the IRS and a drought and it gets a little more difficult and a lot more fun!

—description from the publisher

This is a stand-alone expansion to the original game, with purple and green robot teams and updated rules for more than 2 players. 2 players can play this version by itself, but combined with additional copies of the expansion or the original version of the game, more players can play together.

Play
Players strategically select from their hand of robot cards as they attack and defend. Each time a player defeats their opponent's robot, they become the attacker on the next round. The defender has the advantage of choosing how to respond to the attacker's card, and may choose to sacrifice both robots to attempt to capture the robots in their opponent's hand. When one player runs out of cards, they are defeated and their opponent is the Robot Master of the World!

-description from designer
Compilation of Jockey and Grand Prix.

PucelOca: el juego de Valladolid is an entertaining board game to investigate the history and the most hidden corners of the capital 
The 63-square board combines the dynamics of the game of goose and Trivial Pursuit with 1,200 questions.
Discover what makes Valladolid, may it be artistic, geographical, cultural, religious, political, historical, architectural or environment of the capital.

The game offers 2 game modes: 

     the players establish a time to play or
     advance through the track until reaching the last space 63.


Content:

     rules,
     cards with 1,200 questions / answers,
     4 pawns,
     1 dice

Plamo vs Plamo (abbreviated to PvP) is a tabletop combat game where players design their own mecha combatants and bring their creations to the table to fight. From building to battling, players are given freedom to design and play with units that reflect their personality. Create a model that expresses your style, customize it to fit your needs in-game, and challenge your friends to a game!

PvP's game system is designed to keep players engaged at all times. Whether you're playing one-on-one against an opponent in a duel, playing a scenario requiring careful coordination of your team to complete an objective, or a chaotic six-player battle royale, downtime is short, action is fast, and players are kept making meaningful choices at all times.

A core aspect of PvP is unit customization, and the Unit Design Module allows players to create a huge range of machines both to reflect in-game mechanical diversity and their modelling efforts. The Unit Design Module allows players the freedom to combine Frames, Equipment and Weapons in any way they see fit while working within agreed-upon points limits.

In ãƒ¢ãƒ³ç ”ï¼ï¼(Monken), the players are working at a research institute in a forest filled with monsters.  They explore the forest, respond to requests from the Monster Exploration Association, and breed new types of monsters.

The game is a worker placement game where you must feed your workers, but rather than knowing what action spaces your workers will occupy, to simulate the forest exploration aspect, each location begins the game face down and will return face down after each round, so there is a memory element.

uZito is a balancing game, using pieces of different weights.  The game advertises that it only has one basic rule: take a piece and put it on the top. Additionally, the publisher notes that the rulebook has almost no language in it, and the game can be easily understood through visuals alone.

The games' pieces appear to be floors, metal pillars, abstract muscular humans, large stones, and stacks of medium stones.

In WORMS, each player controls one worm, and the winner will be the person whose worm remains on the board the longest.

Each turn a player choose to roll the blue die or the red die.  If they roll the blue die, they move their worm that many spaces, by pressing their finger on its head, and pulling it around the board. Then, they must add a piece to its tail, but can stop once the worm is 10 sections long.

If your worms runs into another worm, or itself, you have lost.  Your worm will turn into a ghost and will have limited actions you can do on your turn.

If a player rolls the red die, the worm will not move or grow, but there is a chance it will simply be removed.

The last worm alive wins.

1st El Alamein is a simplified simulation of the mid 1942 battle in the desert of Egypt that marks the high tide of the Afrika Korps in the desert.

Although the later battles of Alam Halfa and especially 2nd El Alemein are more famous, it was the Commonwealth’s survival in this July battle that stopped the Afrika Korps and saved Egypt.

Advanced and optional rules based on historical events are included for more experienced players looking for a deeper and more complicated game.

Sequence of play:
Step 1 -Allocate support units
Step 2 –Move any or all Axis units
Step 3 –Axis declare Combats
Step 4– Allies side Movement
Step 5– Allied side declare Combat
Step 6– Move Axis armour units
Step 7- Move Allied armour units
Step 8– Axis armour declare combats
Step 9– Reinforcements
Step 10- Administration
Step 11– Victory Determination

Páirc: A thrilling Gaelic board game is a Hurling and Gaelic Football game.

The objective of the game is to move players around the board and maneuver the ball to score points (1 point) and goals (3 points).
The team with the highest score at the end of the game is the winner.

Content

     1 board
     1 green dice - for player movements and ball challenges resolution
     1 white dice - for ball movement
     2 teams of 15 hurlers
     2 teams of 15 footballers
     32 referee cards - cards are taken when a blank face on a dice is rolled
     32 break of the ball cards
     1 set of scoresheet
     1 small ball for hurling
     1 large ball for football
     30 player bases
     2 sets of goal posts
     1 ruleset

Pencils down is an entertaining game that is an instant favorite for everyone who plays it! Get ready for fun and quick answers as players try to come up with something unique for easy category.

The categories seem simple, but the pressure is on when you have to think of examples starting with the chosen letter. You get more points for answers that no one else thought of, so a little imagination goes a long way!

A fun game for all ages, it’s perfect for parties and get togethers with family and friends!

The epic battle between the navies of France and Britain across the Revolutionary, Directory, Consulship and Empire of Napoleon. Annual turns and four scenarios cover a large number of events from Slave Risings to the Treaty Of Tilsit. The Royal Navy has the odds in its side in combat, but it must control the colonies of the three largest European Empires: The French, Spanish and Dutch. There are merchantmen and privateers to hunt, and all the time the French Army operates safe from most naval interventions. The infant American Republic is all to anxious to take world trade into their bottoms.

World-wide map, colony displays, each counter is 10 battleships or 15 frigates.

—description from the designer

Addit is played with 2 dice on a game board surrounded by numbers. You can push the numbers from one side of the board to the other. The object of the game is to be the first to push all 10 numbers to the other side of the board, by calculating cleverly with the numbers on the dice you have rolled. The first player to press all the numbers wins!

Re-live the last few decades of great music in this fast moving card game based on the chart topping Now That's What I Call Music albums.
Players rolls a die to determine which question they will answer. If they get the answer right they keep the card and place it in front of them, showing the letter on the back.
The first player to spell "N O W !" using the cards wins.

Get all the "Human" players to the center of the game board before the Virus beats them to it. If even one Human is left behind, the Virus wins! The Virus can be ruthless by using "exposure spots" and attack cards to slow the Humans' pace... but if the Humans play their cards right, they might just be able to defend themselves. If not, they risk going into quarantine. Both the Virus and Humans can progress forward by using action cards. But beware, not all actions have positive outcomes! Players can also trade and stock up on the three sacred resources of 2020:  Toilet paper (AKA, 2020 Gold), hand sanitizer (AKA Liquid Life), and groceries (AKA Bare Necessities). Family-friendly. Print-from-home.

—description from the designer

A Cooperative Superhero Deck and Board Building game for a team of 2-4 Players. Each chooses an iconic champion to play as and work together to confront and defeat a central supervillain. Each hero has their own unique starter deck of Origin cards that highlight that character's unique strengths and skills. Each Hero also comes with a Deck of super-powerful Solo Cards that only they have access to, featuring their most powerful abilities.

On their turn, players will explore to add new map panels to the board. Each Map Panel contains new Union Cards to add to their deck. There are also City cards with Challenges to overcome and Enemies to defeat, collecting outrageous rewards. Beyond that, Map Panels have Actions and special set-ups so you never know what's going to be around the corner! Players control how the board is built and a one-of-a-kind Map is constructed each game.

All the while, the Peril of the Supervillain grows, their plot escalates, and they unleash minions, maniacal machinations, and bring their own formidable combat prowess to bear. Each Supervillain has their own means of conquering the city, each time you build the board it is different, and each Hero has their own powers that they can add to and hone as part of your own Union City Alliance!

-description from designer

It's Kind of a Fun Story is a getting-to-know-you storytelling game for acquaintances or a revealing party game for friends you thought you already knew everything about. Players tell stories, compete to best fit card descriptions, and sometimes steal cards from one another, in a bid to get to know each other and win!

To begin, each player takes one 'Nope' card and two 'Hear Me Out' cards. The deck is then shuffled, placed in the center of the table, and ten 'Take a Chance' cards are placed beside it.

On your turn you draw a card and follow its instructions. There are four types of cards. The Story Cards are worth two points, while the others are all worth one.

When you draw a Story Card, you must answer the question on the card, such as 'what was your least favorite job?' or 'who was your arch-nemesis growing up?'. If for some reason you do not wish or do not have a story for the card, you may skip it and draw a new card. Another player may take a skipped card to answer on his turn rather than drawing a new one if he wishes.

If you are the only one who answered the Story Card, you place it in your score pile. However, a player may discard a 'Hear Me Out' card if she also wishes to tell a story for the prompt. Players then vote on who should win the card. If you have already used your 'Hear Me Out' cards, you may place a 'Take a Chance' card into your score pile instead, in order to answer another player's Story Card. These are worth negative one point.

The 'Left or Right' cards require you to decide which player on either side of you best fits the description on the card. The 'Point a Finger' card requires everyone to vote on who best fits the description. Finally, for the 'Everybody Answers' card, each player gives a brief answer to the prompt or question and then votes on who wins the card.

If, during a story, the topic ever veers into territory you are not comfortable with, you simply hold up your Nope Card, and the story immediately ends. There is no penalty and the current player simply draws a new card. Nope Cards are not meant to be used in any competitive fashion, and are simply there to keep everyone comfortable with the game content.

When a player wins a card they place it in their scoring pile. The first player to 7 points wins the game.

Now that that’s out of the way, are YOU ready to lay all your cards on the table?

The game contains 320 cards and an endless amount of stories to be shared.

Trying to keep this PG? All our decks are customizable with Rated-R cards that can be removed if your mom wants in on the fun. (Or keep them, your call).

-description from designer

You are a cultist, trying to establish your faction's rise to power. Fight over rituals and mythical monsters as you seek victory and control of the cult.

				
				
					RolesEach player is given a role that will remain hidden throughout the game, except the High Priest. This role will determine your win condition:

     High Priest - Root out corruption in the cult. Kill all Cabalists, the Heretic, and survive.
     Cabalists - Seek to take control of the cult. Kill the High Priest.
     Faithful - Protect the High Priest from threats to their power. Kill all Cabalists, the Heretic, and the High Priest must survive.
     Heretic - Burn the whole cult to the ground. Kill the entire cult, yourself included if necessary.


				
				
					Extra abilitiesEach player will also be given a:

     Character card that determines their starting health, special ability, and a power symbol that provides an additional way to gain life from the dice.
     Secret sigil card, which gives each cultist a once per game power, will also be given to each player.


				
				
					MechanicsA player will take a turn by first rolling their dice up to 3 times. They then decide where to commit their dice: to rituals to gain altar effects to temporarily empower themselves, finish a ritual in order to gain its powerful effects permanently, stab other cultists, gain life, or give life to other cultists.

If a player is killed, they are not eliminated. Instead, they become a wraith. They will roll dice on their turn still, just less. They cannot commit dice like normal but instead haunt the dice of enemies and allies by giving, replacing, or discarding dice.

-description from designer

A long time ago, two half-serving wizards lived in the depths of an old forest. The two were in training, but one day they were called by their master.

"I will test you from now on. Let's recognize the person who completed" Magical Remedy "first as a full-fledged wizard."

In order to make "magical remedies", plants and minerals, parts of the body of animals and phantom beasts, and "fire (red)" "water (blue)" "earth (yellow)" "trees (green)" You must synthesize "rune stone" that has the magical power of "mineral (white)". You will be one of the wizards and collect medicine materials in the fantasy forest. Then extract the magical power from the "rune stone" and complete the medicine faster than your rivals.

In this game, players take all stones of the same color on either the magic circle card or the center of the table and place them on the icon in their hand. Points will be deducted for stones that cannot be placed or surplus stones. When the stones are buried on the 5 icons in your hand, the card is complete. Get the score written on the card.

If you do not meet the end-of-game conditions, replenish the magic circle card with rune stones and perform the next round. In this way, the player who gets 30 points first is recognized as a full-fledged wizard by the master.

—description from the designer

A Yahtzee variant for children from ages 5 up. Numbers in the dice have been replaced with animals, and you try to roll as many same animals as possible. There are no straights and no bonuses for the upper part of the scoring sheet, so the rules have been simplified quite a bit.

ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ (Mock Word) is word game from Japan with a reversal on the common method. Instead of players trying to identify the hidden word, they have to fit words to hidden categories. The game can be played just for fun, or can be played more seriously to win or lose.

In Mock Word, one player is a Respondent, the other players form the Support, a co-operative team, of which one player is an Ojama. At the start of the game, the team players compose a series of words by secretly writing a single character at a time of cards. The cards get passed around, so each player contributes to forming the words. The Ojama is acting a sort of spoiler, secretly trying to make nonsense words as they form. This can produce hilarious words and makes the game a lot of fun.

Once the words are set, the Respondent tries to identify the theme words that fit each of the composed words. If they can, all the players score points except the Ojama. If the Respondent cannot match the words to the themes, then the Ojama scores points. At the game end, most points wins. 
user summary

Let’s face it — nothing simulates the chaos of the current administration like a combination of rotten vegetables and confetti being dropped on a high-speed fan, but this game is the next best thing!

In this fast-moving card game, each player takes control of a group of government staffers and wins loyalty for their people while stealing it from others, all while trying to avoid the wrath of the president. People will be fired, transferred, and otherwise totally embarrassed, but there can be only one winner! And it sure won't be the nation!


     Based on Stephen Colbert’s animated show Our Cartoon President.
     Provides much needed laugh-out-loud outlet in regards to American Politics!
     Blank Character cards allow you to keep up with political events!


—description from the back of the box

Project is actually an extension of the game Connect, because it uses most of the material from it and develops the main game principles in depth. This time, however, it is a political game in which you try to build various geometric shapes together. But you also get points for encircling your opponent.

The Illumination of Deepsorrow is a standalone expansion for the Legends Untold system which can be enhanced with the addition of the Weeping Caves and Great Sewers Novice Sets. It can also be combined with these products to create a massive catalogue of cards for self-build adventures.
 Deepsorrow introduces:
Four new playable Occupations and Cultures, along with a host of new Weapons, Kits, Outfits and Talents to let you build the character you want.

A new Focus system that allows you to use the mystic teachings of the Nabti Walkers to push your body and mind to the limits of endurance.

New Physiological Talents for the Wrathlander - use natural gifts to survive poison and even channel lightning!

A new Shock Condition that impacts both Heroes and Foes, beware that sparking floor tile!

A new Clues and Epilogues system that rewards exploration – will you brave that Vine Swing Barrier to reveal more about the multiple factions that have an interest in the ancient site?

New Boons and Backpack cards that let you expand your party’s arsenal of options, you must use them wisely to ensure your survival.

New Loot categories including Locked, Sealed, and Heavy, that require you to use all your wits to benefit from them.

A new Treasure deck system for those that always have to find every piece of loot.

A Cinematic Campaign of multiple Plot Arcs, that you must discover and interact as you explore Deepsorrow.

Exhausted, a messenger collapses on the steps of the temple. From his hand a single leaf drops to the floor and a shockwave echoes across the sanctuary. The Monks at Firesorrow have waited millennia for the sign - the Lost Forest has come to life - A Step into Darkness has begun.

Where the sky screams and black clouds roar 
Where the sand climbs high and eagles soar 
Secrets will travel by sail and oar
To Dip’Sa’Ra on distant shore

The violent wind whips sand across your face; overhead the constant lightning of the Wrathstorm earths into the enormous coral-like spires that tower above you. You are sworn to your quest: you must investigate the mysteries of Deepsorrow and find the ancient Illumolith so that you may shine a beacon of light and illuminate the approaching darkness.

-description from publisher

The game is unbranded

The image on the box with coloured scene of climbers and a tent flying the British flag suggests that it was probably published in England after Sir Edmund Percival Hillary and Sherpa mountaineer Tenzing Norgay became the first climbers confirmed to have reached the summit of Mount Everest, on 29 May 1953.

Contents:

     collapsible pyramid with mountain scenes printed in colours;
     printed base with slots for the mountain;
     four coloured, round headed playing pins;
     one wooden dice;
     one dice shaker;


The rules of the game are printed on the underside of the box lid.

Pocket Pairs is a fast-paced game about finding the commonalities among a card collection. A 9-card game where you must cut the cards into 18 1/2-size cards.


Pocket Pairs is a fast-paced card game about collecting cards, then deciding what items they have in common, such as a Pencil and Paper Clip are both found in an office. Add in a Toy Soldier and they all have a pointy bit! Great for teaching associations and developing critical thinking skills.


Released in the November 2016 Board Game of the Month Club $10+ package.

Miss Match is a fun, quick and simple game for 2-12 players of all ages.

Players race to find a link between the cards on the table in fun and creative ways. The cards are always changing so, think fast and shout out a match before someone else can. You keep the cards you matched and that’s how you score points in the game. The more cards you can match at once the more points you score each round.

—description from the designer

"Runeslingers: The Awakening" is a strategic customizable card game that ingeniously melds board game and dueling card game elements into a wholly unique strategy gaming experience. It promises to challenge even the most seasoned gaming veterans with its myriad strategic win conditions, card combinations, and decision trees that confront players each turn.

Take on the role of a Runeslinger, a wielder of magical incantations known as runespells. Much of the game's art features runestones, ancient stone artifacts that empower your Runeslinger with runespells. Each runespell possesses a class affinity that provides guidance on its thematic origins and strategic pairings but does not limit card pairings in deck construction.

The game's objective is straightforward: diminish the enemy Runeslinger's power from five to zero. Achieve this by dealing damage, applying ailments, or discarding the enemy's cards to weaken their power. Reduce the enemy Runeslinger's maximum health to zero, or deplete their entire deck and discard pile to secure instant victory! With five distinct win conditions coupled with a unique ailment system, "Runeslingers" stands as an exceptionally complex yet rewarding strategy game that introduces significant mechanical advancements to the genre.

Customize your Runeslinger with a unique stance and ability to further develop specific strategies, limited only by your creativity. Select from a pool of over 180 unique cards in the Alpha set, and assemble a 40-card deck with no class or color restrictions. Employ six unique ailments that dynamically alter gameplay on a moment's notice. Master the art of shouting, Runeslinger's distinctive take-that mechanic that enables you to disrupt enemy actions, even when it's not your turn!

If you seek a challenging and genuinely strategic game, your search ends with "Runeslingers!"

Show your strategic and collaborative skills in Lost & Found: New Harvest, a historical strategy game of balance between community and family needs.

In this standalone expansion to Lost & Found, players explore how lost and found possessions were addressed under Islamic jurisprudence, as informed by Al-Hidayah and The Distinguished Jurist's Primer. These texts were written in the 12th century by great Islamic scholar and jurists Burhan al-Din al-Marghinani and the polymath Ibn Rushd (Averroes). They provide guideposts for behavior, but it’s up to you to decide how to solve dilemmas.

Set in medieval North Africa, towns are built by families like yours. Take on one of five roles in a struggle to address dilemmas, overcome crises, and avert disasters that threaten to destroy everything you know and love. Look out for your family, but be sure to collaborate with your neighbors as well. Any number of players can win, but if anyone goes destitute, everyone loses.

Explore the ways in which these medieval religious legal systems helped to hold society together and helped to keep neighbors cooperating with one another. Optionally, you can pair Lost & Found: New Harvest with the original Lost & Found and take on both Jewish and Muslim roles, and explore how these laws play out for these two communities living in Fustat (Old Cairo) in the 12th century.

Will you follow the laws of lost and found possessions? Will you break them? Will you go above and beyond the law?

You get to create the classic game Alias yourself! Choose the words of your liking and write them on the cards. The game itself plays like a regular Alias, a word explanation game where you explain words without reveiling the word itself (or a part of it): whether they are synonyms, antonyms or whatever works best in the situation, this party game sure makes it fun to play with words - and now with the new DIY cards!

In D.I.Y. Alias players come up with their own words based on the topics in the cards. Once you have a word in mind, write it on the card, start explaining and let the other players guess. The first player to reach the finish wins the game!

Content: Double-sided game board, 300 cards, sand timer, rules.

While this is not meant to be the be all and end all of space combat systems, and it will most definitely not be the most complicated of them, it is and will be what we envisioned it to be oh those many years ago when we put together a one page set of rules so that we could play with our miniature toys in the kitchen and in the garage on the weekends.

—description from the rulebook

The game ãƒˆãƒ©ãƒ³ãƒ—å†é›†è¨ˆ!! (Trump Recount!!) consists of a board which shows a map of the United States, with some "battleground" states in white, and other states colored red or blue, to represent their political leanings in the 2020 United States' presidential election.  The game board lists 13 battleground states, and places to play cards for each state along the edge.  (Players must provide their own cards.) The map has a scale showing the progress of J.BIDEN and D.TRUMP towards an electoral college victory.

One player takes the red cards (diamonds and hearts) from a deck of cards, and the other player takes the remaining suits (clubs and spades). First the players gather their heart and spade cards, and, beginning with the red player, alternate placing cards at the 13 battleground states.  Then, the players do the same with the other suits.

Afterwards, the "counting" phase begins, and players have several options, such as to privately count a state and either declare victory or announce that the counting is still in progress; recount a state where your opponent has declared victory; ask for a public recount; or pass.

If any player declares defeat, the opponent's side wins. If neither player declares defeat, the game will never end.

In Summon Skate you play a Figure Skater. No, not the kind you’re thinking. Instead you are a summoner who skates out complex magical diagrams to summon Figures - mythical gods and creatures - to fight giant monsters of chaos in high-speed, tactical battles.

The gameplay of Summon Skate is divided between puzzle solving/investigation and tactical combat. Players will check out strange happenings in their city to piece together the true nature of the chaos manifesting there. These investigations generally involve making checks using the simple 3 Attribute, 2D6 roll-under resolution system. Once the mystery is solved, the chaos gathers and takes on a physical form born from human nightmares - a Chaos Figure, the main enemies of this game.

Once combat with the Chaos Figure begins, the players are teleported to a magical stage represented by a 12 x 12 grid. Each turn, players must use their limited movements points to draw out summoning diagrams on the grid. Once a diagram is completed, players can summon the Figure tied to the diagram. Summoned Figures are the primary means of fighting, guarding, healing and supporting in the game. Meanwhile the enemy Chaos Figure will spend its turns trying to either kill the player characters directly or shatter the stage by creating cracks that extend from one side to the other. If all the players run out of HP or the stage is completely shattered, it’s game over and the world falls to chaos. You’ll need cooperation and planning to make it through these battles alive.

—description from the designer

Doubloons is a 2-6 player card game of pillage and plunder. Take the helm of a pirate ship in a race for 7 doubloons. Along the way, hire the help from history's most prolific pirates like Samuel Bellamy, Anne Bonny, Ching Shih, and more.

It takes less than 5 minutes to learn. There are two types of cards in the game: action cards and pirate cards. Each player receives 5 action cards to start. On your turn, you draw an action card and then can play up to 3 action cards. Action cards allow you to do things like collect doubloons, draw cards, and steal from other players.

You can choose to spend doubloons in order to recruit pirates onto your crew. These pirates give you effects that can be used once on every turn. Different combinations of action cards and pirates allow you to accelerate your path to victory and decelerate your opponents.

—description from designer

As a successful Magician, you have been able to fund a lifetime of research by delivering to the petty demands of liars, philanderers, gluttons and the least of Humanity.

How refreshing, then, when a client should emerge with a commission of horrifying simplicity that has the potential for acquiring a vast amount of knowledge - perhaps the ultimate knowledge - albeit at the expense of many millions.

"Release the denizens of Hell into the Earth, with Baphomet - The Sabbath Goat - at their Head, for one night only and let them run amok. Let us see the consequences - for aesthetic reasons only, of course."

However, do not expect this matter to proceed without interference from the Church and/or from Hell itself: the best-laid plans do not always go the way expected.

Inspired by the Black Easter novellas by James Blish, the aim of Aleph Null is to successfully summon the demonic Prince Baphomet who, when he appears, expects there to be no cards in your hand, the main deck and the discard pile; if there are any cards remaining in these ‘zones’, you lose. However, ‘not losing’ in this way doesn’t mean that you have won: any cards still in play also count against you – too many and you shall lose also. The sooner you ‘win’, the better your chance of surviving any due punishment.

—description from the designer

In Food Time Battle in Space in Space, you are a restauranteur in the 1950s trying to take advantage of the recent colonization of the moon in this alternate version of Earth.

This game is a lite engine-building card game for 2-4 players with a healthy amount of randomness, but heaps of strategy, with four different decks, and four different playstyles to choose from.

Your goal is to be the first restaurant to five stars, and you do this by completing critic orders with your ingredients. You have to place ingredients down in the correct order, and to gain critic perks (which help you later in the game) you have to use luxury ingredients as well.

These critic perks are used to increase your handsize, redraw cards, play cards in different orders and discard cards, all in the name of creating the perfect meal for other critics. These abilities are your engine!

—description from the designer

ULUS is a game aimed at preserving knowledge about Mongolian culture. It is published by the Endangered Alphabets Project, which strives to preserve the many writing systems of the world that are under threat of extinction, including the Mongolian alphabet.

The game is set at the time after Genghis Khan's death, when his successors wondered what form the huge Mongolian empire should have in the future. Should the nomadic culture be preserved? Should Mongols adapt to an urban culture?

Each player adheres to one such idea, asks the support of a deity and a totemic animal and begins to gather the assets that will help their idea to prevail. The game is divided into two phases. The first phase is mostly to gather assets and to attack other players to thwart their plans. Players can choose to play an attack card which the attacked player can defend against. The player of the weaker card will lose strength points which will make it harder to fulfill their tasks in phase two. Alternatively, players can pass or try to force a trade on another player. If they know about a card another player holds, they can ask for it in exchange for any other asset card.

In phase two of the game, players arrive at the great summer festival of Naadam. Here, they compete in three traditional Mongolian sports: archery, horse racing and wrestling. Winners are decided by adding asset modifiers to a player's strength. 
After a final round of trading or attacking, players reveal their collected assets and add their strength to determine the winner.

Rules will be included in English and Mongolian.

In Noche de Juerga ("Binge Night") you have to get 6 cards that are obtained by visiting different places in a city (squares) and do some challenges that are proposed in these.
Once achieved, you must reach the central square.

The first to get it wins

The fun of the game are in challenges proposed during its progress.

—user summary

En el juego hay que conseguir 6 tarjetas que se obtienen visitando distintos lugares de una ciudad (casillas) y hacer algunas pruebas y retos que se proponen en éstas.
Una vez conseguidas se debe llegar a la casilla central.

El primero en conseguirlo, gana

Lo divertido del juego son las pruebas y retos propuestos durante el desarrollo de éste.

—user summary (Spanish)

The goal of Bits & Bytes is for each player to guide their character (program) to their home by issuing instructions (turn right, turn left, move forward, turn around). At the same time they have to avoid walls, bugs and the dreaded Seepeeu (pronounced CPU).

Sounds simple, right? But that’s the point.

Children are playing a card game, but at the same time they are creating computer concepts, like algorithms and the sequencing of instructions, and they are learning the invaluable skill of problem solving. And by doing so they are developing a logical mind-set, which is required for coding/programming. By playing Bits & Bytes, children are developing the logical foundations for programming computers, thus when they start to learn actual coding later in life they already have the required mindset. After all, actual coding (programming) is little more than issuing a few instructions to a computer.

A game of escalation where everyone can lose.

Inspired on the one hit wonder song 99 Red Balloons by Nena.

Our second month of One Hit Wonders is based on 99 Red Balloons, which was a one hit wonder in the US, but one of many in Nena's native Germany. Other hits include Irgendwie, irgendwo, irgendwann and ? (Fragezeichen).

Designed by Suzanne Zinsli (of Cardboard Edison) this is a neat trick taking game where players are trying to reach the end of the cold war track (9 spaces) before the world war track reaches 9, with 9's being trump!

—description from the publisher


A standard deck of cars is dealt evenly among the players.

A token for each player is put at the beginning of the Cold War track, and another token is put in the World War track.

In each round, every player clockwise takes an action:
- Escalate: play a higher card in the same suit, or any card if you don't have any in suit.
- Stand down: pass until next round.
- Challenge: Play a 9 card (trump, black 9s, and super trump, red 9s).

Play continues until all but one player passes, or if two same-color 9s are played. The player who played the highest on-suit card (or trump or supertrump) takes all the cards played this round.

Set aside all 9s played each round. When all four 9s are played, the hand is over. At the end of the hand, discard any cards in your hand, then add up points for the cards you collected by winning rounds.

If your score was positive, advance your token in the Cold War track. Then, if any player has negative points, take the lowest score and add it to the World War track. If any player reaches the end of the Cold War track, they win. If the World War track reaches its end before any player wins, everyone loses.


99 is a postcard game sent to Board Game of the Month Club subscribers in the February 2017 package.
